Metadata.Title: The Application Is Partitioned into Public And Private Domains
Metadata.DirectLink: The Application Is Partitioned into Public And Private Domains

Content.Data:
What to Check For

Ensure that your application clearly defines the boundaries between its protected and unprotected resources.

Why

Defining a boundary between public and restricted content helps establish the check points that will allow access to the restricted content.

How to Check

Follow these steps to ensure your application is partitioned into public and protected (restricted) domains:

  1. Enumerate all web accessible resources. Identify the protected resources from the public resources. Common protected resources include but are not limited to:

    • Resources that require authentication
    • Critical application resources
    • Sensitive/confidential data

  2. Ensure that protected resources have the appropriate access controls. Determine if all protected resources have the appropriate access controls assigned to them.

  3. Check if there is separation on disk between public and protected resources. Examine the local filesystem structure. Check if a protected resource is located inside a public directory and vice versa.

  4. Verify the local system permissions for all resources. For each resource, check that the local system permissions are set accordingly. If the resource is public, verify that anonymous users can access it. If the resource is protected, verify that only authorized users can access it.

How to Fix

Defining the boundary requires:

  1. Determine roles. Define the various types of users and their rights. Build a security policy for the restricted content and base the user groups' privileges around it.

  2. Define the boundary. Structure the content according to access and logical orders. Try to use a modular approach when establishing the boundary.

  3. Separate on disk. Once the boundaries have been established, reflect these boundaries onto the local file system. Separate the restricted content from the public content on disk.

  4. Set proper permissions. Set proper permissions to the restricted content. Dedicate a special directory for the restricted content and require valid access before accessing content within this directory. These permissions can be enforced at the application, server and operating system levels, depending on the environment in use.

Authorization Guidelines

  • Perform Role-based Security Checks
  • Require Authentication and Authorization for All Sensitive Pages
  • Make Authentication and Authorization Policies Configurable
  • Deny All Access by Default
  • Check Access Control Permissions When Referencing Objects
  • Use Indirect Object References
  • Partition the Application Between Public and Private Domains
  • Secure the Account Administration Functionality
  • Automatically Lock Inactive User Accounts
  • Consider Using JAAS for Authorization

Authorization Checklists

  • Role-based Security Checks Are Performed
  • Authentication and Authorization Are Required for All Sensitive Pages
  • Authentication and Authorization Policies Are Configurable
  • All Access Is Denied by Default
  • Access Control Permissions Are Checked When Referencing Objects
  • Indirect Object References Are Used
  • The Application Is Partitioned into Public and Private Domains
  • Account Administration Functionality Is Secured
  • Inactive User Accounts Are Automatically Locked
